result.execSummary:
The defendant Lucas D Smillie was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Theft-Movable Property >$2500-$5000, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

chargeModifiers.descr: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime

miscConds.notes:
Pay restitution in the amount of $1850.00. Restitution is joint and several with co-defendants.
------------------------------

Pay court costs and Department of Corrections Supervision Fees.  If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment may be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.  Collections may include income assignment.
------------------------------

No illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia.  No alcohol. No contact with the victim. No contact with the co-defendants.
------------------------------
Counseling as recommended by Probation Agent.  Provide biological specimen to state crime lab for DNA analysis, and pay DNA analysis surcharge.

timeConds.notes: with work release privileges to commence on or before March 6, 2015 @ 8:00 am. Conditional release jail time may be served in Jefferson County. Defendant may serve conditional release jail time on electronic monitoring if available to him.
The defendant is to complete one-hundred (100) hours of community service work during his period of probation with NO BUYOUT.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Lucas D Smillie

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: 12:08 pm  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given.  Defendant Lucas D Smillie appeared, Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Probation Agent Nina Hanfler appears by phone.  Matter is before the Court for a probation review hearing.  Defendant is due to discharge from probation and has outstanding court obligations.  Agent Hanfler states that Defendant has been making payments but he has 2 cases - he also has a Jefferson County case.  Discussion as to whether any restitution has been paid by deft on either his Walworth County or Jefferson County case.  Defendant says he has made payments.  Defendant says he does work.  He lives with his wife and 3 kids.  She doesn't work - she is going to school.  Deft will be getting an advanced payment from his employer to pay off his court obligations.  Agent expresses confusion over the information she has with regard to defendant's payments because it seems to show restitution is paid.  Court orders 1 year extension of probation and defendant's probation can  terminate once his court ordered financial obligations are paid in full.  Agent Hanfler is going to need to figure out exactly what Mr. Smillie now owes so that Mr. Smillie can know what he has to pay to get his obligations paid off in full.   Court asks that Agent prepare an Order extending probation Mr. Smillie's probation for one year.  If his obligations are paid in full prior to his current discharge date, then his probation will not need to be extended.
Probation review hearing on December 15, 2016 at 11:00 am.

records.descr: Notice of court ordered financial obligations
Notice and acknowledge of def voting ineligibility

records.addlTxt: Defendant Lucas D Smillie in court with attorney James B. Duquette.  Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Minutes filed.

Defendant Lucas D Smillie in court with attorney James B. Duquette.  Haley Jo Rea appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Matter is before the Court for a Final pre-trial.  Parties confirm they are prepared to proceed to trial on Monday of next week.  They are not aware of any pre-trial issues that need to be addressed at this time.  State is to file Jury Instructions by noon on Friday.  Minutes filed.

Defendant Lucas D Smillie in court with attorney James B. Duquette.  Diane M. Donohoo with special prosecutor Tracy McMiller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Minutes filed.  Jury trial - 12 person scheduled for January 12, 2015 at 08:30 am.  Final pre-trial scheduled for January 7, 2015 at 02:30 pm.
Defendant stands mute. Court enters not guilty plea and speedy trial reserved but not demanded at this time.

Defendant Lucas D Smillie in court with attorney Ashley Renz for  James B. Duquette.  Daniel A. Necci appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Minutes filed.  Status conference scheduled for October 8, 2014 at 01:15 pm.
Plaintiff's Demand and Motion for Discovery and Inspection.  Notice of Motion and Motion for Establishment of Discovery Deadlines.
Original Warrant filed with the court.
Signed bond filed with the court.

Defendant is to be booked and printed within twenty-four (24) hours.  Defendant will not in any way contact or attempt to contact any victim(s) listed and will avoid their residence/place of employment or any place they are located and will avoid causing any other person, other than defendant's attorney, from doing so on defendant's behalf.  The term "no contact" is hereby defined as through the mail, by telephone, by way of electronic device, in person, or through a third party.  VICTIM(S)/RESIDENCE(S): NO CONTACT WITH J.D. OR HIS RESIDENCE. NO CONTACT WITH WITNESSES S.S. OR L.C. OR THEIR RESIDENCES. NO CONTACT WITH CO-ACTORS MICHAEL MILLER AND SEAN MUELLER.   Defendant shall personally ensure that payments are made under any Order for Income Withholding if the Court appoints an attorney for the defendant.
